title: Theresa May under fire over threat to leave the EU without a trade deal
text:

Prime Minister Theresa May has come under fire over her threat to quit the EU without a trade deal rather than to agree to a “bad” deal. 
Mrs May said in January that “no deal for Britain is better than a bad deal for Britain”. 
But County Durham MP Phil Wilson contrasted that stand with her apparent determination to agree a trade deal with the US, as he questioned her in the House of Commons. 
And the UK’s former ambassador to the EU said a “cliff-edge” Brexit with no exit deal would be “insane” and economically damaging for the European Union and Britain. 
Speaking during the Prime Minister’s weekly question and answer session, Mr Wilson referred to a speech delivered by Mrs May at Lancaster House, London, in January. 
He said: “In the Prime Minister’s Lancaster House speech, she said of a future trade agreement with the EU, ‘no deal for Britain is better than a bad deal for Britain’. 
“In the spirit of consistency, will that rule also apply to any future trade negotiations with the United States of America, where President Trump has said that America comes first?” European workers including nurses, social workers and teaching assistants protest outside the Houses of Parliament in London before lobbying MPs over their right to remain in the UK (Photo: PA) 
She told him: “I have said consistently, we will be ensuring that when we negotiate trade deals with whichever countries around the world, they will be good deals for the UK.” 
Meanwhile, Sir Ivan Rogers, who quit as the UK’s ambassador to the EU in January, said the consequences of the UK falling into a “legal void and relying on World Trade Organisation rules would be “nuts” and both parties need to strike a deal. 
Appearing before the Commons Brexit Select Committee, he pointed out that Bank of England governor Mark Carney has said such a scenario could pose a risk to eurozone stability. Read More The high price Sunderland and Newcastle could pay for Brexit revealed 
Sir Ivan said: “There are other consequences in other sectors which would make it an insane thing to do.” 
He added: “This (the EU) is a very legalistic body that we are dealing with and they will say you have transformed yourselves overnight from having been a member of this body to a third country outside the body and in the absence of a new legal agreement everything falls away. 
“We all know that that’s nuts in the real world, because why would you want to stop UK planes flying into European airports.
